node.title: Secure 2.0: Here are 5 ways it could impact your retirement
node.description: The bipartisan bill could solve some savings gaps facing workers at a time when many Americans are unprepared for retirement.

node.title: Indonesian principal sentenced to death for raping at least 13 girls
node.description: Herry Wirawan was accused of raping girls between 11 and 14  from 2016 to 2021 at the school, hotels or rented apartments in the city of West Java. At least nine babies reportedly were born as a result of the rapes.

node.title: Biden administration aims to fix "family glitch" in health care law
node.description: The proposed fix would help 200,000 uninsured people gain health care coverage, according to the Biden administration.

node.title: Auckland water bills going up 7% from July
node.description: Inflation and Covid-19 being blamed - and with the price for 1000L of water will go up by about 12 cents, households with average water use will pay about $1.50 more a week.

node.title: Local body elections 2022: where it will heat up
node.description: It's local elections year, and politicians up and down the country are hoping to be re-elected or pick up a seat for the first time on local bodies. Audio

node.title: Luxon labels Putin a war criminal, again urges ambassador's removal
node.description: National's leader Christopher Luxon has gone a step further than the prime minister, labelling Russian President Vladimir Putin a war criminal.

node.title: Government finances resilient but Omicron impact yet to be felt
node.description: The government's finances have stood up better than expected in the face of the surge in Covid-19, but the government is warning the full cost of Omicron is yet to be felt.

node.title: 'Now or never' to limit climate warming, IPCC scientists say
node.description: The key UN body says in its report that there must be "rapid, deep and immediate" cuts in carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions.

node.title: Covid-19 update: 14,120 community cases, 23 further deaths, 692 people in hospital
node.description: There are 14,120 community cases of Covid-19 and 23 further deaths to report today.

node.title: Investigation uncovers shocking NZ SAS statements about Australian soldier in East Timor
node.description: Secret documents reveal that New Zealand special forces witnessed the alleged brutalisation of militia corpses in East Timor by an Australian SAS soldier.

node.title: Hearing on judge should continue on public interest grounds, panel told
node.description: A hearing to determine whether a judge accused of misconduct should be investigated, despite the fact they no longer hold office, has wrapped up this afternoon.

node.title: Vandals destroy 18 kilometres of road signs and letterboxes
node.description: More than $12,000 of road signage has been destroyed on a crime spree in the Motueka Valley.

node.title: Chance to home Kaimanawa wild horses extended
node.description: The application process for people to adopt wild horses from Kaimanawa Ranges has been extended in a bid to save more horses.

node.title: Initial confusion reinforces need for caution on Air NZ's $1.2b plan - regulator
node.description: Potential investors are being urged to seek professional advice if they are considering taking part in Air New Zealand's capital raising.

node.title: 'Extraordinary place': Iwi fearful of fire damage to Waituna Wetland
node.description: The head of Te Rūnaka o Awarua says the Southland wetlands are extremely significant with tīpuna buried nearby.

node.title: Tonga police name New Zealand couple found dead on island of Vava'u
node.description: Deputy Police Commissioner Tēvita Vailea said their bodies were discovered by police at their resort home in the village of 'Utungake on the afternoon of Saturday 2 April.

node.title: Building industry urges delay to energy efficiency code
node.description: The industry says members are suffering from stress amid escalating costs and disruptions to supply and labour, and the code should be delayed a year.

node.title: Parliament debates to touch business nerves
node.description: If ever there was a week in parliament to make the business sector a little itchy, this week might just be it.

node.title: Zelenskyy to address U.N. Security Council
node.description: The Ukrainian president's remarks will be delivered as evidence grows that Russian troops purposely killed civilians — alleged actions he's called "genocide" but that Russia denies.

node.title: ACC mixed up files of two people with similar names
node.description: ACC mixed up the files of two people with similar names and sent the medical notes of one to the other.

node.title: Headaches both good and bad for Silver Ferns' selectors
node.description: We're a quarter of the way through the ANZ Premiership, but how much can we read into the results so far after a Covid-disrupted start? Sports reporter Bridget Tunnicliffe analyses the first few…

node.title: New car sales hit a record high as buyers rush to beat the Clear Car Discount
node.description: Figures from the Motor Industry Association show 21,044 cars were sold in March, which beat the previous record in October 2018 by 4,374 vehicles.

node.title: Chris Fleming announces exit from top health role
node.description: Chris Fleming will step down as chief executive of Southern DHB when it transitions to the new Health New Zealand authority on 1 July.

node.title: Expulsion of Russian ambassador 'an absolute option for us' - Ardern
node.description: The Prime Minister is defending the ongoing presence of the Russian ambassador in New Zealand, but says expulsion remains on the table.

node.title: Evidence 'piling up' of war crimes in Ukraine - Mahuta
node.description: Foreign Affairs Minister Nanaia Mahuta says evidence is "piling up" of war crimes by Russia in Ukraine, but would not go so far as labelling President Vladimir Putin a war criminal. Audio

node.title: More Russian oligarchs added to New Zealand sanctions register
node.description: The 36 oligarchs and family members added include Chelsea football club owner Roman Abramovich, but not the owner of the luxury Helena Bay Lodge in Northland.

node.title: Unearthed moa bones at least 180,000 years old
node.description: Bones discovered during construction work on Te Ahu a Turanga: Manawatū Tararua Highway have been aged to be at least 180,000 years old and possibly up to 345,000 years.

node.title: Axed liquor licensing policy back on Hamilton Council agenda
node.description: The council is revisiting the policy after ditching it four years ago due to pressure from the liquor industry.

node.title: Death in the streets of Ukraine
node.description: Ukranian officials are accusing Moscow of war crimes following the discovery of hundreds of bodies in the liberated city of Bucha, northwest of Kyiv.

node.title: Wider surveillance testing to watch for XE variant, winter illnesses - Bloomfield
node.description: It is inevitable new Covid-19 variants such as the newly discovered XE strain will arrive in the country, Director-General of Health Ashley Bloomfield says. Audio
